stem: A client with an indwelling catheter has a temperature of 102.8Â°F (39.3Â°C), heart rate 124, and BP 82/40. The client remains hypotensive after a 2L fluid bolus. Complete the clinical bowtie.

actions.text: Administer furosemide to reduce fluid overload

rationale.correct: Septic shock is characterized by systemic inflammation (c1) and massive vasodilation (c2). Since fluid boluses failed, norepinephrine (a1) is needed. Cultures (a2) are diagnostic. MAP (p1) and Lactate (p2) are the primary monitoring parameters for shock resolution.
rationale.incorrect: Furosemide (a3) would worsen the shock by further reducing preload. Oral antibiotics (a4) are too slow; IV is required.

clinicalPearls: Target MAP is typically >= 65 mmHg in septic shock.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Don't be afraid to keep giving fluids or start pressors in sepsis; do not give diuretics even if the client looks 'edematous'.
